intro: Brassica erigens, commonly known as the mountain mustard, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe and Asia. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops such as cabbage and broccoli. The plant typically grows to a height of 30 to 100 centimeters, featuring yellow flowers arranged in racemes. Its leaves are usually lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stem is often hairy and somewhat woody at the base. Brassica erigens is often found in rocky or gravelly soils and is adapted to cooler climates.
